summary: This document is a series of forwarded emails from whistleblower Christopher J Dilorio to various recipients, primarily judges and SEC officials, alleging massive securities fraud, money laundering, and regulatory corruption involving Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial (NITE/VIRT), the SEC, and other financial entities. Dilorio claims the SEC is obstructing justice, protecting criminal enterprises, and denying his whistleblower awards while facilitating ongoing frauds that pose systemic risk.

persons.name: Christopher J Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of securities fraud, money laundering, and SEC corruption related to Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial and other entities. He claims to have filed multiple TCRs (Tip, Complaint, or Referral) and is appealing a denied whistleblower award.

persons.name: Cifu
persons.context: Referenced as admitting the importance of retail/OTCM share volumes to NITE/VIRT's revenue model. Allegedly involved in accounting fraud and the corrupt VIRT/KCG merger.

persons.name: Blostein
persons.context: A sell-side analyst at Goldman Sachs who Dilorio claims knows that OTCM share volumes drive NITE/VIRT revenue but omits this from his models, constituting fraud.

persons.name: Handler
persons.context: Repeatedly mentioned as having a corrupt, criminal relationship with the SEC and Jefferies, benefiting from the fraudulent VIRT/KCG merger and ongoing obstruction.

persons.name: Kamensky
persons.context: Referenced as someone whose freedom and life have been ruined, and who must receive Dilorio's information to achieve justice. Implied to be a victim of the SEC/SDNY actions.

persons.name: Judge Cave
persons.context: One of the primary recipients of Dilorio's emails, being appealed to regarding SEC corruption and the need for disclosure in Kamensky's case.

persons.name: Judge Jones
persons.context: Another primary recipient of Dilorio's emails, alongside Judge Cave, being informed of alleged SEC fraud on the court.

persons.name: Repetto
persons.context: A sell-side analyst mentioned who may have been promised business or threatened regarding NITE/VIRT. Asked to answer questions about red flags.

persons.name: Fannon
persons.context: Another sell-side analyst mentioned alongside Repetto, asked to answer questions about NITE's financials.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Former SEC Chairman accused of not recusing himself from Dilorio's award denial and the VIRT/KCG approval despite conflicts from his previous firm Sullivan & Cromwell (Sull Crom) and colleague Jared Fishman.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: A Sullivan & Cromwell colleague of Jay Clayton accused of playing a key role in keeping NITE/VIRT operational and involved in the 2017 'glitch' cover-up.

persons.name: Norberg
persons.context: Referenced as creating 'extraordinary reasons' for denying Dilorio's whistleblower award, including the claim that 'SEC investigators never saw my information'.

persons.name: Janey
persons.context: Addressed in multiple emails regarding the failure to produce the record for Dilorio's award appeal and allegations of SEC corruption protecting Net Element and other frauds.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: SEC official copied on emails, accused of being part of the criminal obstruction and failure to properly handle Dilorio's whistleblower information.

persons.name: Berger
persons.context: The SEC official with whom Dilorio filed his 2013 Knight TCR.

persons.name: Joshie Sason
persons.context: Alleged 'bag man' involved with Hanover/Magna in fraudulent schemes (CGFIA, IMDS, NewLead, etc.). Subject of an SEC complaint that Dilorio claims is based on his information.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Alleged 'bag man' involved with JMJ in money laundering shells, barred by FINRA as a 'Bad Actor'. Later involved with Blink Charging (fka New Image Concepts).

persons.name: Crede
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to Net Element (NETE) fraud, money laundering, and connections to Putin/Rakishev/Trump/Kushner/Alfa.

persons.name: Peizer
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Crede in relation to Net Element fraud and fraudulent offerings via Esousa and Cobblestone.

persons.name: Milken
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to Net Element fraud and connections to entities like Esousa and Cobblestone.

persons.name: Ajay Tandon
persons.context: Defendant in an SEC complaint against SeeThruEquity for pump-and-dump promotion of Net Element (NETE), which Dilorio had alerted the SEC to.

persons.name: Amit Tandon
persons.context: Defendant in an SEC complaint against SeeThruEquity for pump-and-dump promotion of Net Element (NETE).

persons.name: Richard Best
persons.context: Mentioned as bringing a FINRA complaint against Brown Brothers Harriman (BBH) based on Dilorio's information.

connections.description: Dilorio accuses Cifu of securities fraud, accounting fraud, and being part of a corrupt scheme with the SEC and Handler to facilitate the fraudulent VIRT/KCG merger.
Dilorio alleges a 'criminal, corrupt relationship' between the SEC and Handler/Jefferies to protect NITE/VIRT, facilitate fraudulent mergers, and obstruct justice.
Both are colleagues from Sullivan & Cromwell (Sull Crom). Dilorio alleges Fishman played a key role in keeping NITE/VIRT running and that Clayton had conflicts he did not disclose.
Alleged to have orchestrated the VIRT/KCG merger with the SEC, using fraudulent balance sheet items to inflate the acquisition price while knowing KCG was insolvent.
Blostein is an analyst covering NITE/VIRT. Dilorio claims Blostein knows Cifu admits retail/OTCM volumes drive revenue but omits this from his models, possibly under threat from Cifu.
Both are described as 'bag men' involved in fraudulent schemes involving money laundering shells and convertible notes, with their activities detailed in Dilorio's TCRs.
Dilorio is corresponding with Janey (SEC OWB) regarding his award appeal, accusing Janey of failing to produce the record and being part of the obstruction.
Mentioned together as involved with Net Element (NETE) fraud, money laundering, and connections to Russian figures and Trump/Kushner.

events.title: Knight Capital 'Glitch'
events.description: A trading glitch at Knight Capital that caused a massive loss, which Dilorio claims proved his allegations that Knight was insolvent and was the first cover-up of the underlying fraud.

events.title: VIRT/KCG Merger Closing
events.description: The $1.4 billion all-cash merger of KCG Holdings and Virtu Financial. Dilorio alleges it was fraudulent, with the SEC/Handler/Cifu writing down over $4 billion in 'naked short fails' from KCG's balance sheet just before closing to hide insolvency.

events.title: Dilorio's Initial Knight TCR Filed
events.description: Christopher Dilorio filed his first Tip, Complaint, or Referral (TCR) with SEC official Berger, alleging abusive naked shorting and fraud at Knight Capital.

events.title: SEC Preliminary Denial of Dilorio's Opco Award
events.description: The SEC's Office of the Whistleblower (OWB), via Janey and Norberg, preliminarily denied Dilorio's award application related to his Opco information. Dilorio claims this is part of a scheme to run out the clock and protect criminals.

events.title: SEC Complaint Against SeeThruEquity
events.description: The SEC filed a complaint against SeeThruEquity, LLC and the Tandon brothers for pump-and-dump schemes, including promoting Net Element (NETE). Dilorio claims this was based on information he provided.

events.title: SEC 'Shell Factory' Complaint (Jaclin et al.)
events.description: The SEC filed a complaint against individuals involved in a 'shell factory' scheme, which included New Image Concepts (later Blink Charging). Dilorio notes Keener later became involved with this shell.

keyFacts: The whistleblower, Christopher J Dilorio, alleges that Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial's (NITE/VIRT) core business is 'abusive naked shorting' of OTC Markets (OTCM) shells to facilitate money laundering, and that this drives their profits.

Dilorio claims the SEC has engaged in a 'massive criminal obstruction scheme' to protect NITE/VIRT, Handler/Jefferies, and other entities, including by writing down over $4 billion in 'naked short fails' from KCG's balance sheet before the 2017 merger to hide insolvency.

The document alleges a corrupt relationship between the SEC, Handler (of Jefferies), and NITE/VIRT executives like Cifu, facilitating fraudulent mergers and misleading the public about the company's true business model.
Dilorio connects the fraud to broader networks involving money laundering, Russian figures (Putin, Rakishev), and U.S. political figures (Trump, Kushner) through entities like Net Element (NETE).

The SEC is accused of using Dilorio's whistleblower information to bring selective enforcement actions (e.g., against Sason, Keener, SeeThruEquity) while protecting the main perpetrator, NITE/VIRT, and denying his rightful award.
